title: What is Kali Haldi and why it is considered an endangered herb in India | The Times of India
description: Scientifically known as Curcuma Caesia or Black Zedoary, this turmeric species is also known as Kali Haldi in Hindi, Yaingangamuba in Manipuri, Borangshaga in the Monpa community (Northeast India), BeiAchomba in the Sherdukpen community of Arunachal Pradesh. This perennial herb has a bluish-black rhizome and thrives well in moist deciduous forest areas in clayey soil.
cleaned_text: 02/6What is black inner part of the rhizome is bluish-black in colour and releases a pungent, camphor-like aroma with mildly spicy and bitter undertones. The rhizomes are not commonly consumed on their own due to their hot, sharp, sour, and earthy taste, and they sometimes carry a subtle turpentine-like flavour mixed with bitterness.
